revision.comment: Archiving; ratings no longer shown on EW and LAT sites
revision.text:
{{use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox album | name = "Love and Theft" | type = studio | artist = [[Bob Dylan]] | cover = Bob Dylan - Love and Theft.jpg | alt = A greyscale photograph of Dylan's face with the text "BOB DYLAN" at the top left | released = {{Start date|2001|9|11}} | recorded = May 2001 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Folk rock]], [[blues rock]], [[country blues]], [[roots rock]], [[electric blues]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]] | length = {{Duration|m=57|s=25}} | label = [[Columbia Records|Columbia]] | producer = [[Bob Dylan|Jack Frost]] (Bob Dylan's pseudonym) | prev_title = [[Live 1961–2000: Thirty-Nine Years of Great Concert Performances]] | prev_year = 2001 | next_title = [[The Bootleg Series Vol. 5: Bob Dylan Live 1975, The Rolling Thunder Revue]] | next_year = 2002 }} '''''"Love And Theft"''''' (generally referred to as '''''Love and Theft''''') is the 31st studio album by American singer-songwriter [[Bob Dylan]], released on September 11, 2001, by [[Columbia Records]]. It featured backing by his touring band of the time, with keyboardist [[Augie Meyers]] added for the [[recording session|sessions]]. It peaked at #5 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], and has been certified [[gold album|Gold]] by the [[RIAA]].[https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS RIAA website retrieved 03-12-10]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070626051113/http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS |date=June 26, 2007 }} A limited edition release included two [[bonus tracks]] on a separate [[compact disc|disc]] recorded in the early 1960s, and two years later, on September 16, 2003, this album was remixed into 5.1 [[surround sound]] and became one of fifteen Dylan titles reissued and [[remastered]] for [[Super Audio CD|SACD]] playback. ==Content== The album continued Dylan's artistic comeback following 1997's ''[[Time Out of Mind (Bob Dylan album)|Time Out of Mind]]'' and was given an even more enthusiastic reception. The title of the album was apparently inspired by historian [[Eric Lott]]'s book ''Love & Theft: Blackface Minstrelsy and the American Working Class,'' which was published in 1993. "''Love and Theft'' becomes his ''[[Fables of the Reconstruction]]'', to borrow an [[R.E.M.]] album title", writes Greg Kot in the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' (published September 11, 2001), "the myths, mysteries and folklore of the South as a backdrop for one of the finest [[roots rock]] albums ever made." The opening track, "Tweedle Dee & Tweedle Dum", includes many references to parades in Mardi Gras in New Orleans, where participants are masked, and "determined to go all the way" of the parade route, in spite of being intoxicated. "It rolls in like a storm, drums galloping over the horizon into ear shot, guitar riffs slicing with terse dexterity while a tale about a pair of vagabonds unfolds," writes Kot. "It ends in death, and sets the stage for an album populated by rogues, con men, outcasts, gamblers, gunfighters and desperados, many of them with nothing to lose, some of them out of their minds, all of them quintessentially American. {{quote|They're the kind of twisted, instantly memorable characters one meets in John Ford's westerns, Jack Kerouac's road novels, but, most of all, in the blues and country songs of the 1920s, '30s and '40s. This is a tour of American music—jump blues, slow blues, rockabilly, Tin Pan Alley ballads, Country Swing—that evokes the sprawl, fatalism and subversive humor of Dylan's sacred text, Harry Everett Smith's ''Anthology of American Folk Music,'' the pre-rock voicings of Hank Williams [Sr.], Charley Patton and Johnnie Ray, among others, and the ultradry humor of Groucho Marx.}} Offered the song by Dylan, [[Sheryl Crow]] later recorded an up-tempo cover of "[[Mississippi (Bob Dylan song)|Mississippi]]" for her ''[[The Globe Sessions]]'', released in 1998, before Dylan revisited it for ''Love and Theft''. Subsequently the [[Dixie Chicks]] made it a mainstay of their [[Top of the World Tour|Top of the World]], [[Vote for Change]], and [[Accidents & Accusations Tour]]s. As music critic [[Tim Riley (music critic)|Tim Riley]] notes, "[Dylan's] singing [on ''Love and Theft''] shifts artfully between humble and ironic...'I'm not quite as cool or forgiving as I sound,' he sings in 'Floater,' which is either hilarious or horrifying, and probably a little of both."{{cite web|url=http://www.publicbroadcasting.net/wrni/arts.artsmain?action=viewArticle&sid=4&pid=1&id=306241|title=Lay Down Your Weary Tune|first=Tom|last=Riley|date=September 13, 2001|website=www.publicbroadcasting.net|accessdate=June 29, 2018}} "''Love and Theft'' is, as the title implies, a kind of homage," writes Kot, "[and] never more so than on 'High Water (for [[Charley Patton]]),' in which Dylan draws a sweeping portrait of the South's racial history, with the unsung blues singer as a symbol of the region's cultural richness and ingrained social cruelties. Rumbling drums and moaning backing vocals suggest that things are going from bad to worse. 'It's tough out there,' Dylan rasps. 'High water everywhere.' Death and dementia shadow the album, tempered by tenderness and wicked gallows humor." "'Po Boy', scored for guitar with lounge chord jazz patterns, 'almost sounds as if it could have been recorded around 1920," says Riley. "He leaves you dangling at the end of each bridge, lets the band punctuate the trail of words he's squeezed into his lines, which gives it a reluctant soft-shoe charm." The album closes with "Sugar Baby", a lengthy, dirge-like ballad, noted for its evocative, apocalyptic imagery and sparse production drenched in echo. Praising it as "a finale to be proud of", Riley notes that "Sugar Baby" is "built on a disarmingly simple riff that turns foreboding." ==Recording== This album has been incorrectly cited as being recorded digitally into [[Pro Tools]].{{citation needed|date=January 2011}} This album was recorded to a Studer A800 mkIII @ 30ips on BASF/Emtec 900 tape at +6/250 nanowebers per meter. Pro Tools was used solely for editing of specific tracks and was thus used very sparingly. Whatever work was done in Pro Tools was flown right back to the {{convert|2|in|mm|adj=on}} masters. It was mixed from the {{convert|2|in|mm|adj=on}} masters to an Ampex ATR-102 1-inch 2-track customized by Mark Spitz at ATR Services.{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}} In an interview conducted by Alan Jackson for ''The Times'' Magazine in 2001, before the album was released, Dylan said "these so-called connoisseurs of Bob Dylan music... I don't feel they know a thing, or have any inkling of who I am and what I'm about. I know they think they do, and yet it's ludicrous, it's humorous, and sad. That such people have spent so much of their time thinking about who? Me? Get a life, please. It's not something any one person should do about another. You're not serving your own life well. You’re wasting your life." ==Reception== {{Album reviews | MC = 93/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/love-and-theft/bob-dylan |title=Reviews for Love and Theft by Bob Dylan |website=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=July 14, 2015}} | rev1 = [[AllMusic]] | rev1Score = {{rating|4.5|5}}{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/love-and-theft-mw0000012576 |title=Love and Theft – Bob Dylan |website=[[AllMusic]] |accessdate=October 31, 2015 |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |authorlink=Stephen Thomas Erlewine}} | rev2 = ''[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]'' | rev2Score = {{rating|5|5}}{{cite magazine |url=http://blender.com/guide/reviews.aspx?ID=3372 |title=Bob Dylan: "Love and Theft" |work=[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]] |last=Wolk |first=Douglas |authorlink=Douglas Wolk |accessdate=October 31, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060630075539/http://blender.com/guide/reviews.aspx?ID=3372 |archivedate=June 30, 2006 |url-status=dead}} | rev3 = ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' | rev3Score = {{rating|3.5|4}}{{cite news |url=http://www.jimdero.com/News2001/Sept10Dylan.htm |title=Dylan's labor of 'Love' |work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |date=September 10, 2001 |accessdate=October 31, 2015 |last=DeRogatis |first=Jim |authorlink=Jim DeRogatis}} | rev4 = ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' | rev4Score = A−{{cite magazine |url=http://www.ew.com/article/2001/09/10/love-and-theft |title=Love and Theft |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=September 10, 2001 |accessdate=October 31, 2015 |last=Browne |first=David |authorlink=David Browne (journalist) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20190403134227/https://ew.com/article/2001/09/10/love-and-theft/ |archivedate=April 3, 2019 |url-status=dead}} | rev5 = ''[[The Guardian]]'' | rev5Score = {{rating|3|5}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2001/sep/07/artsfeatures3 |title=One for the Bobcats |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=September 7, 2001 |accessdate=October 31, 2015 |last=Petridis |first=Alex |authorlink=Alexis Petridis}} | rev6 = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' | rev6Score = {{rating|4|4}}{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/sep/09/entertainment/ca-43694 |title=This Year's Dylan Is a Sonic Dynamo |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=September 9, 2001 |accessdate=October 31, 2015 |last=Hilburn |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert Hilburn |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161112071949/http://articles.latimes.com/2001/sep/09/entertainment/ca-43694 |archivedate=November 12, 2016 |url-status=dead}} | rev7 = ''[[Q (magazine)|Q]]'' | rev7Score = {{rating|4|5}}{{cite magazine |title=Bob Dylan: "Love and Theft" |work=[[Q (magazine)|Q]] |issue=182 |date=October 2001 |page=122}} | rev8 = ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' | rev8Score = {{rating|5|5}}{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/love-and-theft-20010904 |title=Love and Theft |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=September 27, 2001 |accessdate=October 31, 2015 |last=Sheffield |first=Rob |authorlink=Rob Sheffield}} | rev9 = ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' | rev9Score = 9/10{{cite magazine |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m-qexhnZaukC&lpg=PP1&dq=spin%20nov%202001&pg=PA127 |title=The Jack of Hearts |work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]] |volume=17 |issue=11 |date=November 2001 |accessdate=October 31, 2015 |last=Light |first=Alan |authorlink=Alan Light |pages=127–28}} | rev10 = ''[[The Village Voice]]'' | rev10Score = A+{{cite news |url=http://www.robertchristgau.com/xg/cg/cgv901-01.php |title=Consumer Guide: Minstrels All |work=[[The Village Voice]] |date=September 18, 2001 |accessdate=October 31, 2015 |last=Christgau |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert Christgau}} }} In a glowing review for his "Consumer Guide" column published by ''The Village Voice'', Robert Christgau wrote: "If ''[[Time Out of Mind (Bob Dylan album)|Time Out of Mind]]'' was his death album—it wasn't, but you know how people talk—this is his immortality album." Later, when ''[[The Village Voice]]'' conducted its annual [[Pazz & Jop]] Critics Poll, ''Love and Theft'' topped the list, the third Dylan album to accomplish this.{{cite news|url=http://www.robertchristgau.com/xg/pnj/pjres01.php |title=Pazz & Jop 2001: Album Winners |newspaper=[[The Village Voice]] |accessdate=2007-10-07 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202234415/http://www.robertchristgau.com/xg/pnj/pjres01.php |archivedate=December 2, 2013 }}{{cite news|url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2018/01/22/pazz-jop-top-10-albums-by-year-1971-2016/ |title=Pazz & Jop: Top 10 Albums By Year, 1971-2016 |newspaper=[[The Village Voice]] |accessdate=2018-11-21}} It also topped ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'}}s list.{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/31233826/the_year_in_recordings_the_top_10_albums_of_the_year_2001/5 |title=The Year in Recordings: The Top 10 Albums of the Year 2001 |work=Rolling Stone |date=December 27, 2001 |accessdate=March 28, 2014 |author=[[David Fricke|Fricke, David]] |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100208035801/http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/31233826/the_year_in_recordings_the_top_10_albums_of_the_year_2001/5 |archivedate=February 8, 2010 }} ''[[Q magazine|Q]]'' listed ''Love and Theft'' as one of the best 50 albums of 2001.{{cite magazine |title=The Best 50 Albums of 2001|magazine=Q|date=December 2001|pages=60–65}} ''[[Kludge (magazine)|Kludge]]'' ranked it at number eight on their list of best albums of 2001.{{cite magazine |last1=Perez|first1=Arturo|title=Top 10 Albums of 2001|url=http://www.kludgemagazine.com/articles.php?id=88|website=[[Kludge (magazine)|Kludge]]|accessdate=November 25, 2015|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20040722004951/http://www.kludgemagazine.com/articles.php?id=88 |archivedate=July 22, 2004}} In 2012, the album was ranked #385 on [[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Albums of All Time]], while ''[[Newsweek]]'' magazine pronounced it the second best album of its decade.{{cite news | url =http://2010.newsweek.com/top-10/best-albums/love-and-theft-bob-dylan.html| title = #2 'Love and Theft' Bob Dylan | accessdate = 2009-12-27| work = Newsweek | date = 2009-12-11 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100106200749/http://2010.newsweek.com/top-10/best-albums/love-and-theft-bob-dylan.html| archivedate=January 6, 2010}} In 2009, [http://www.glidemagazine.com/ ''Glide Magazine''] ranked it as the #1 Album of the Decade.[http://www.glidemagazine.com/articles/55436/glides-best-albums-of-the-decade.html "Glide's Best Albums of the Decade"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130509180104/http://www.glidemagazine.com/articles/55436/glides-best-albums-of-the-decade.html |date=May 9, 2013 }} ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' put it on its end-of-the-decade, "best-of" list, saying, "The predictably unpredictable rock poet greeted the new millennium with a folksy, bluesy instant classic."Geier, Thom; Jensen, Jeff; Jordan, Tina; Lyons, Margaret; Markovitz, Adam; Nashawaty, Chris; Pastorek, Whitney; Rice, Lynette; Rottenberg, Josh; Schwartz, Missy; Slezak, Michael; Snierson, Dan; Stack, Tim; Stroup, Kate; Tucker, Ken; Vary, Adam B.; Vozick-Levinson, Simon; Ward, Kate (December 11, 2009), "THE 100 Greatest Movies, TV Shows, Albums, Books, Characters, Scenes, Episodes, Songs, Dresses, Music Videos, and Trends That Entertained Us over the Past 10 Years". ''Entertainment Weekly''. (1079/1080):74-84 The album won the [[Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Folk Album]] at the [[44th Annual Grammy Awards]]. It was nominated for Album of the Year and the track "Honest with Me" was nominated for [[Best Male Rock Vocal Performance]]. ==Allegations of plagiarism== ''Love and Theft'' generated controversy when some similarities between the album's lyrics and Japanese writer [[Junichi Saga]]'s book ''[[Confessions of a Yakuza]]'' were pointed out.This is a reprint of an article from ''The Wall Street Journal'' as cited in next footnote. {{cite news| url = http://www.csudh.edu/dearhabermas/plagiarbk010.htm| title = Did Bob Dylan Lift Lines From Dr Saga? | access-date = September 7, 2008 | publisher = California State University, Dear Habermas | date = July 8, 2003| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080724053350/http://www.csudh.edu/dearhabermas/plagiarbk010.htm| archivedate=July 24, 2008}}{{cite news | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10576176194220600?mod=home_page_one_us | title = Did Bob Dylan Lift Lines From Dr Saga?| access-date = September 7, 2008| newspaper = [[Wall Street Journal]] | date = July 8, 2003}} Translated to English by [[John Bester]], the book is a biography of one of the last traditional [[Yakuza]] bosses in Japan. In the article published in the ''Journal'', a line from "Floater" ("I'm not quite as cool or forgiving as I sound") was traced to a line in the book, which said "I'm not as cool or forgiving as I might have sounded." Another line from "Floater" is "My old man, he's like some feudal lord." One line in the book's first chapter is, "My old man would sit there like a feudal lord." However, when informed of this, author Saga's reaction was one of having been honored rather than abused from Dylan's use of lines from his work.[[Sean Wilentz|Wilentz, Sean]]. ''Bob Dylan in America''. {{ISBN|978-0-385-52988-4}}, p. 310. ==Track listing== {{Tracklist | all_writing = [[Bob Dylan]] | headline = Side one | extra_column = Recorded | title1 = Tweedle Dee & Tweedle Dum | length1 = 4:46 | extra1 = May 8, 2001 | title2 = [[Mississippi (Bob Dylan song)|Mississippi]] | length2 = 5:21 | extra2 = May 21, 2001 | title3 = Summer Days | length3 = 4:52 | extra3 = May 8, 2001 }} {{Track listing | headline = Side two | extra_column = Recorded | title4 = [[Bye and Bye]] | length4 = 3:16 | extra4 = May 12, 2001 | title5 = Lonesome Day Blues | length5 = 6:05 | extra5 = May 11, 2001 | title6 = Floater (Too Much to Ask) | length6 = 4:59 | extra6 = May 12, 2001 }} {{Track listing | headline = Side three | extra_column = Recorded | title7 = [[High Water (For Charley Patton)]] | length7 = 4:04 | extra7 = May 17, 2001 | title8 = Moonlight | length8 = 3:23 | extra8 = May 16, 2001 | title9 = Honest with Me | length9 = 5:49 | extra9 = May 9, 2001 }} {{Track listing | headline = Side four | extra_column = Recorded | total_length = 51:42 | title10 = Po' Boy | length10 = 3:05 | extra10 = May 16, 2001 | title11 = Cry a While | length11 = 5:05 | extra11 = May 18, 2001 | title12 = [[Sugar Baby (song)|Sugar Baby]] | length12 = 6:40 | extra12 = May 19, 2001 }} {{Tracklist | total_length = 8:20 | headline = Limited edition bonus disc [[digipak]] release | title1 = I Was Young When I Left Home | note1 = Recorded December 22, 1961 | length1 = 5:24 | title2 = [[The Times They Are a-Changin' (song)|The Times They Are a-Changin']] | note2 = Alternate version, recorded October 23, 1963{{cite web |author=Olof Björner |title=Still on the Road: 1963 Concerts and Recording Sessions: Studio A, Columbia Recording Studios, New York City, New York, 23 October 1963, The 4th The Times They Are A-Changin' session, produced by Tom Wilson |url=http://www.bjorner.com/DSN00340%201963.htm#DSN00590 |accessdate=August 27, 2010}} | length2 = 2:56 }} ==Personnel== * [[Bob Dylan]] – [[Singing|vocals]], [[guitar]], [[piano]], [[producer (music)|record production]] * [[Larry Campbell (musician)|Larry Campbell]] – guitar, [[banjo]], [[mandolin]], [[violin]] * [[Charlie Sexton]] – guitar * [[Augie Meyers]] – [[accordion]], Hammond B3 organ, Vox organ * [[Tony Garnier (musician)|Tony Garnier]] – [[bass guitar]] * [[David Kemper]] – [[drums]] * Clay Meyers – [[bongos]] * Chris Shaw – [[recording engineer|engineering]] ==Charts== {| class="wikitable" !Year !Chart !Peak
position |- |rowspan=1|2001 |[[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] |rowspan=1|5{{cite web|title=Bob Dylan - Chart history {{!}} Billboard|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/293235/bob-dylan/chart?f=305|website=www.billboard.com|accessdate=15 April 2017|language=en}} |} ==Certifications== {{certification Table Top}} {{certification Table Entry|type=album|region=New Zealand|artist=Bob Dylan|title=Love and Theft|award=Gold|id=1149|relyear=2001|accessdate=3 June 2019}} {{certification Table Entry|type=album|region=Sweden|artist=Bob Dylan|title=Love and Theft|award=Gold|certyear=2001|relyear=2001|}} {{certification Table Entry|type=album|region=Switzerland|artist=Bob Dylan|title=Love and Theft|award=Gold|certyear=2001|relyear=2001|}} {{certification Table Entry|type=album|region=United Kingdom|artist=Bob Dylan|title=Love and Theft|award=Gold|certyear=2013|relyear=2001|}} {{certification Table Entry|type=album|region=United States|artist=Bob Dylan|title=Love and Theft|award=Gold|salesamount=757,000 |salesref={{cite web|url=https://mudcat.org/thread.cfm?threadid=93649|title=New Dylan Album : 'Modern Times'|first=Max|last=Spiegel|publisher=}}|certyear=2001|relyear=2001|}} {{certification Table Bottom}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Bob Dylan}} {{RollingStoneAlbum}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Love And Theft}} [[Category:2001 albums]] [[Category:Albums produced by Bob Dylan]] [[Category:Blues albums by American artists]] [[Category:Bob Dylan albums]] [[Category:Columbia Records albums]] [[Category:Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Folk Album]] [[Category:Albums involved in plagiarism controversies]]
